function_call.name: classify_risks_framework
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Contagious diseases spread in built environments","category":"Structures","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Overlaps and repetitions in biophilic design elements may lead to confusion in interpretation and implementation.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Diverse nature attributes and their classification in architectural design","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Divergent elements in nature-based architectural design theories","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Low"},{"name":"Psychological experience of nature in architectural design","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Ambiguous terminology around ’experience of space and place’ and its relation to contact with nature","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Overlap and ambiguity in the categorization of nature-related elements in the frameworks","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Requirement for specific arrangements for producing pleasurable experiences in nature-related spaces","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Close contact in congested areas may facilitate the spread of contagious diseases.","category":"Structures","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of natural elements and outdoor exposure may impact mental health and immune function.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Biophilic design may be misinterpreted or misapplied, leading to ineffective implementation of nature-based elements in architecture.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequate incorporation of nature-based elements in architecture may result in a lack of human-nature connection and reduced well-being for building occupants.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Failure to consider the cultural and ecological context of natural elements in biophilic design may lead to insensitivity or disconnection with the local environment and community.","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Ambiguity in the definition of 'natural spaces' and 'biophilic design' may lead to inconsistent interpretation and implementation.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of clarity in taxonomies of 'nature' in the frameworks may result in misinterpretation and inappropriate application of biophilic design principles.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Differences in interpretations and frameworks may lead to conflicting design approaches and criteria for biophilic design in practice.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Negative psychological effects of certain 'nature' elements , fear of snakes, spiders leading to mental health impacts.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Inadequate understanding of biophilic design principles leading to inefficient integration of 'nature' in architecture.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"The emotional need for 'nature' is explained as an inherited affection from the experience of choosing habitats and building dwellings, which can lead to a preference for natural characteristics in modern architectural spaces.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Contact with natural features vegetation and water can generate a quick and positive psychological reaction, reducing negative emotions and fostering recovery from physiological stress and health problems.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Connecting to the local natural environment through incorporating regional features geomorphology and landscape in buildings could generate the 'sense of place' and 'sense of community' and realize personal identity, belonging, and cohesion.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Focus on human contact with natural systems and processes in the built environment could lead to the spread of contagious diseases through exposure to natural elements.","category":"Structures","confidence":"High"},{"name":"The theory of biophilia and the instinctive human need for contact with nature may lead to a greater likelihood of exposure to infectious agents present in natural elements.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Contagious diseases transmission in built environment due to close interactions and shared spaces.","category":"Structures","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Use of snowball method to identify publications may result in biased selection of literature, leading to incomplete understanding of biophilic design.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Low"},{"name":"Selection of limited literature on the development of relevant concepts may lead to a narrow perspective on the emergence of biophilic design.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Limited representation of interdisciplinary knowledge may restrict the applicability of biophilic design to address contagious disease propagation in the built environment.","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Potential for transmission of contagious diseases through physical contact with natural elements in biophilic design buildings.","category":"Structures","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of awareness and understanding of biophilic design principles leading to improper implementation and maintenance of natural elements.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of contact with nature in the built environment","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Criticism of 'green-washing' or 'placebo' strategies related to nature in architecture","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Lack of understanding of the emotional needs of humans for interactions with the natural environment in the building environment","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Biophilia leading to close contact with infectious organisms or vectors","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Shift in focus of biophilia theory leading to neglect of human-nature relationship","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Lack of access to gardens, parks, or countryside during covid-19 with natural sceneries in suburban villas","category":"Structures","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Use of front porches to link houses and nature","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Ambiguous definition of 'nature' in architecture may lead to misunderstandings and debates about its
